lines:
1956

17 March, 1917.

Mr. S. C. Luk 
Canton-Hankow Railway 
Ksien Ning city

Hupi, China.

My dear Luk:

Again I am reminded of your unfailing friendship and

interest in the receipt recently of your card with its cordial

New Year's greetings.

Those greetings I am glad to return to you

in the fullest measure, even though my lotter does not bear the date

of January 1st.

How well I remember the Chinese New Year as I caxeitin 
contact with its celebration in your land only a few years ago. At 
Canton and Hongkong particnlarly the festivities were in full force, 
and I myself was on more than one occasion Invited to share in them. 
The atmosphere of 3821y good fellowship and generous good will that 
prevailed everywhere made a deep and lasting impression upon me. I

shall not forget it.

I wish you might feel free to drop me a line now and then

telling me of yourself, your progress and your plans for the future.

Mrs. Hall and I invariably speak of you whenever we meet.

You have

@amed a war place in our affection and we are ever hungering for

more news about you.

Please accept my warmest personal regards and my best

wishes for the highest successes that the world has to offer those

who serve her most truly and best.

Your sincere i wiend always,

metadata.abstract: Letter with New Year greetings to Luk, recalling Stearns' experience of Chinese New Year in China a few years earlier. He asks Luk for more letters describing himself, his progress, and his future plans.
metadata.collection: Head of School (Stearns) correspondence with Chinese alumni
